person.note: There is no problem with the Hebrew transliteration of this name. For the Aramaic א suffix, see Introduction 2.4.2.8. The name is also recorded in Palmyran characters and Stark, PNPI, 64, claims that this is the male name ̓́Αγαθος, with an Aramaic suffix.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
See Introduction 6.3.1.4. She is described in Josephus (AJ 17:141) as a Jewish slave in Rome. It is likely that she was brought there from Palestine, but there is no absolute proof thereof.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.
On the Hasmonean Greek names see Introduction 1.2.4.3.
On second names see Introduction 6.1.3.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.
Named after her grandmother (Alexandra no. 1), see Introduction 3.1.1. See also above, n. 2.
See above, n. 4.
See above, n. 2, and also Ilan,JSJ24 (1991).
See above, n. 3.

Named after her grandmother (Alexandra no. 1), see Introduction 3.1.1. See also above, n. 2.
See above, n. 4.
Named after a distant relative (probably Alexandra no. 3), see Introduction 3.1.3. On Herodians see Introduction 1.2.4.4.
See above, n. 4.

The inscription determines the gender of this person. It seems that, like ̓Αλεξάνδρος, ̓Αλεξάνδρα was also Aramicized and abbreviated in this form, see Introduction 2.4.2.10, and see under Alexander, no. 7. On men and women bearing the same names see Introduction 1.5.2.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

In Coptic characters, see Introduction 2.8.4. This is the suggested reading of the editor, based on other texts. See NHC, 98.

She is mentioned together with other of Jesus’ female disciples known from NT – Mary, Martha and Salome. And see further on this list in R. Bauckham, “Salome the Sister of Jesus, Salome the Disciple of Jesus and the Secret Gospel of Mark,” Nov Test33 (1991) 257-9.
All figures appearing in apocryphal Christian documents are considered fictitious, see Introduction 6.2.2.
She is Jesus’ supposed disciple, so she must have lived during the 1st C CE.
This declension is recorded in the document.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

There is no problem with the Hebrew transliteration of this name. For the Aramaic א suffix, see Introduction 2.4.2.8. Note, however, that בלוזמא in rabbinic literature means “drinking of spiced wine” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 171).
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
Her father was Costobarus (Ilan, Nov Test 34 [1992] 29-30). On Herodians see Introduction 1.2.4.4.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

person.bibl: BJ2:217;AJ18:132 (Schalit,NB, 26); Acts 25:13 (VKGNT 158); Quintilian,GLAJJ1, 513; Tacitus,GLAJJ2, 9-14; Juvenal,GLAJJ2, 99; Suetonius,GLAJJ2, 126-7; Dio Casius,GLAJJ2, 378; Epitome de Ceasaribus,GLAJJ2, 645; OGIS428.
person.note: This is the way the name is transliterated in Quintilian, Tacitus and Suetonius, see Introduction 2.8.2.
This is the way the name is transliterated in Juvenal, see Introduction 2.8.2.
This is the way the name is transliterated in the Epitome de Ceasaribus, see Introduction 2.8.2.
Named after her grandmother (Berenice no. 1), see Introduction 3.1.1. For more on this woman with bibliography, see Ilan, Integrating Women, 92-7. On Herodians see Introduction 1.2.4.4.
See above, n. 3.
Named after her great-grandmother (Berenice no. 1), see Introduction 3.1.3. On Herodians see Introduction 1.2.4.4.
See above, n. 3.
So in Acta Pilati. The shorter form (Βερν instead of Βερεν) is usual (e.g. WGE 206, 207). She is also mentioned in Coptic Bartholomew (Budge, Copt. Apoc. 10 – ΒερεΝικн – in Coptic).
So in Vindicta Salvatori, which was preserved in Latin, see Introduction 2.8.2.

This story names the nameless Gospels heroin (e.g. Mark 5:25-34). See Introduction 1.1.2.2. The apocryphal heroin of Jesus’ passion (the woman with the towel, on which Jesus portrait was impressed) was only added to the equation in the late Latin Vindicta Salvatori, see D. H. Farmer, The Oxford Dictionary of Christian Saints (Oxford 1987) 422.
All figures appearing in apocryphal Christian documents are considered fictitious, see Introduction 6.2.2.
The events of this composition take place close to Jesus’ crucifixion.
See above, n. 11.
Using the Greek form, we can determine that this is the name intended and that the missing ר is the result of a scribal error, see Introduction 2.7.1.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
The declension is recorded in the document, see Introduction 2.3.5.1.
This could also be construed as a nickname, indicating Artemon’s place of origin (the town of Berenice in Cyrene), see Introduction 6.1.1.
See above, n. 18.

This is the suggested reading of the editor. The proliferation of Herodian names in this cave makes the reading very likely, see Introduction 1.2.4.4.1. See also above, n. 11. On the extreme abbreviated spelling see Introduction 7.6.5.1.
On dating of this cave see Introduction 7.6.5.

So in Se 64, although this is clearly the same women.

This is the suggested reading of the editor. It is based on the name of the other women buried in the same chamber, and thus makes sense. For the missing ια see Introduction 2.7.1.

On the interchange of ει and ε see Introduction 2.3.2. This form is recorded on Egyptian papyri (Preisigke, NB, 102; Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 107).
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
This declension is recorded in the document.

This woman is described on the ossuary as Σελυκ, perhaps indicating her place of origin as Seleucia in Syria, as are other people of this burial cave. See Introduction 6.3.1.3. On the other hand, this may be a truncated form of her father’s name – Seleucus.
See above, n. 3.
This is the way the queen’s name is transliterated in rabbinic literature.
Described by Josephus, AJ 20:17. as a native of Adiabene. See Introduction 6.3.1.
On second names see Introduction 6.1.3. Her first name was (the probably Persian) צדן.
See Introduction 6.3.3. The information about her conversion comes form Josephus AJ 20:34-8. Rabbinic literature knows nothing of her conversion (Ilan, Integrating Women, 66-7).
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.
There is no problem with the Hebrew transliteration of this name. For the Aramaic א suffix, see Introduction 2.4.2.8.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
This is a reading suggested by the editor. It may be modeled after the transliteration of the male name, ̔Ελλήνιος.
On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.
This declension is recorded in the document.
This sarcophagus was found in a tomb in conjunction with many ossuaries, see Introduction 7.6.1.

This is probably an idiosyncratic orthography of the name. The form ̔Ηροῦς (̔Ηροῦτος) is documented on Egyptian papyri (Preisigke, NB, 125; Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 127).
See above, n. 3.
On Herodians see Introduction 1.2.4.4.

All figures appearing in apocryphal Christian documents are considered fictitious, see Introduction 6.2.2. On the possible historicity of this character, however, see Kokkinos,PEQ 118 (1986).
Describes the life and death of Herod Antipas’ daughter, not long after Jesus’ crucifixion.
This declension is recorded in the document. On names in this cave see Introduction 1.2.4.4.1.
On dating of this cave see Introduction 7.6.5.

Porath, Atiqot37 (1999) 48*, suggests reading ̔̔Ηρωνᾶς, but this is unlikely because of the archaeological context, in which Herodian names abound and because the name ̔Ηρῳδιάδος appears in the same cave as well.
See above, n. 7.

This is the suggested reading of the editor. This could also be the male name ̔Ηρω́δης, but the ι makes this form more likely. On the extreme abbreviated spelling see Introduction 7.6.5.1. On the names in this cave see Introduction 1.2.4.4.1.
Or “of Tiberias.” In Greek – Τιβέρις.
See above, n. 7.

There is no problem with the Hebrew transliteration of this name. On the ה suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.8. See also תפלס (Theophilus no. 3). Note, however, that תפלא means “child” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1686) and תפלה means “tasteless” or prayer in Hebrew (Jastrow, ibid.).
On dating of ossuaries, see Introduction 7.6.1.
This could also be construed as a nickname, see Introduction 6.1.1.

There is no problem with the Hebrew transliteration of this name. On the ה suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.8. Note, however, that אידא means hand in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 45).
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
I assume this is the transliteration of this name, having retained a Greek case suffix.

On the names of Jesus’ sisters see Bauckham, Jude, 37-44. He thinks this name is secondary, but that we know their historical names (Mariam no. 14 and Salome no. 5). See Introduction 1.1.2.2.
All figures appearing in apocryphal Christian documents are considered fictitious, see Introduction 6.2.2.
Described as being born before Jesus to Joseph and a different wife.

So in the Latin version, see Hist. Ioseph. 2 (Tischendorf, EA, 123), and also see Introduction 2.8.2. For the Greek name ̓Ασία see WGE, 156.

On the names of Jesus’ sisters see Bauckham, Jude, 37-44. He thinks this name is secondary, but that we know their historical names (Mariam no. 14 and Salome no. 5). See, however, Introduction 1.1.2.2.
All figures appearing in apocryphal Christian documents are considered fictitious, see Introduction 6.2.2.
Described as being born before Jesus to Joseph and a different wife.

On the assumption that this woman is named after the previous, see Rosenfeld, IEJ 38 (1988) 240, and see also Schwartz, IEJ 40 (1990) 53, who claims, based on the word υἱῶν following this name, that this person is a male. I can suggest two other ways of reading this inscription, which would refute this premise: 1. The Greek υἱῶν refers here to a son and a daughter mentioned together. 2. The word υἱῶν refers to the three (or two) names following it (̓Αλκίου, Σίμωνος, Γώβαρ), who are sons of Πυρίνος and Μαλθάκη.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

It has been suggested by Peuch,RB90 (1983) 524, that this word is a translation of the Hebrew נפש and means “soul” i.e. “sepulchral monument,” but since no similar examples exist, I suspect that here too a name is intended.

It is not clear which of the two names, mentioned above, n. 1, is intended. Both are recorded but this (combined form) is not.
